repnme.cdata!: Angola - Second Social Action Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is substantial; Bank
            performance is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is
            satisfactory. The project has contributed to a number of
            lessons as follows: 1) For the Bank to be effective in a
            conflict/post conflict context, a quick and flexible
            response is required.  2) The demonstration effect of a
            transparent and accountable institution in an environment
            where nothing seems to work has a tremendously positive
            impact on institutional development. FAS evolved into a
            credible institution through its ability to function with
            transparent fiduciary procedures. It set an example of good
            governance for both the public and the private sector. It
            was therefore able to attract significant resources from its
            development partners (donors and private sector). 3)
            Continuity of staffing in a conflict/post conflict context
            helps to deliver goods and services.  4) Developing
            partnerships and enhancing capacity of partners such as
            churches and nongovernmental organizations who provide the
            interface with communities, contributes to identification of
            innovative sub-projects and leveraging of operational costs.
            Training of such partners can ensure consistency in
            community participation tools. 5). The requirement of having
            two women out of five community nucleus members has helped
            to increase female representation, however, the reality of
            this participation needs to be closely monitored and
            supported with training programs. 6) Define social impact
            indicators upfront. To be able to monitor and measure the
            impact of a project on social capital, a clear definition of
            practical indicators (including an appropriate baseline) is required.

repnme.cdata!:
Angola - Second Social Action Fund Project
            : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Social Action Fund Project
            will improve access to basic services for the poor in rural,
            and peri-urban areas, through the rehabilitation of
            community infrastructure in health, education, and
            sanitation, as a follow-up of the first phase. Therefore,
            the second phase includes roads rehabilitation, and,
            construction of small bridges, market buildings, small-scale
            irrigation, and reforestation sub-projects. However, this
            environmental assessment identifies a special concern
            regarding the "chimapacas", shallow water
            reservoirs, with severely degraded, stagnant water, but a
            major source of drinking water, which endangers health, with
            the increased risk of malaria. Mitigating measures address:
            1) construction, and use of chimpacas should not be
            considered, rather through technical assistance, a properly
            designed well system should be built for human consumption
            needs. In addition, capacity building should be increased
            within the local water departments, and, monitoring of water
            quality established, through environmental technologies; 2)
            soil erosion, water pollution, and flooding should be
            controlled by limiting infrastructure rehabilitation to the
            dry season, through appropriate disposal of oil and solid
            wastes, and, re-vegetation practices to restore natural
            habitats; 3) irrigation systems should ascertain groundwater
            uses, build drainage systems to prevent water-logging, and,
            create terraces, or contour ploughing to slow runoffs; and,
            4) sanitation, and hygiene education, to train communities
            on the uses of new facilities, and, on the operation, and
            maintenance of water systems.

repnme.cdata!:
Angola - Second Social Action Fund Project
            (FAS II)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Social Action Fund
            Project's (FAS II) objective is to increase the
            sustainable utilization of basic social and economic
            services by target populations. The project consists of
            three components: 1) Social and economic infrastructure
            subprojects will support a wide range of small, medium and
            large-scale subprojects for the expansion and improvement of
            basic social and economic infrastructure, as well as the
            provision of training in operation and maintenance of the
            facilities. The subprojects will be identified by poor
            communities, implemented with the assistance of an
            implementing partner, and coordinated with local government
            representatives, nongovernmental organizations, and sectoral
            agencies. They are related to education, health, water and
            sanitation, small-scale community infrastructure, and
            environmental infrastructure. 2) Capacity building will go
            beyond pursuing community participation in its operation by
            supporting independent civil society through training
            programs to strengthen the institutional and managerial
            capacity of local organizations. 3) Strengthening the
            monitoring and evaluation system (M&E) will a)
            capitalize on the existing strengths of the M&E system
            and project cycle of FAS I, and b) address the areas for
            improvements and gaps that were identified at the end of FAS I.
